Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story:
I was reviewing the project timeline on my laptop, sprawled on the living room floor, when I heard my dog barking again in the hallway. The sound echoed off the shared walls, and I winced, imagining Mrs. Lee next door sighing in frustration. As a neighbor, I knew I should keep the noise down, especially since our building was notorious for thin walls. But as an architect, my mind was tangled in deadlines and site visits, and I’d been letting things slide—walking the dog at odd hours, sometimes forgetting to hush him when he got excited by footsteps near the shared doors.

My phone buzzed with a reminder about a project check-in, and I glanced at the clock. I was supposed to be reviewing the contractor’s progress, but all I could think about was the tension in the hallway, the way my neighbors’ eyes lingered on me and my dog. I felt pulled in two directions: the expectation to be a considerate neighbor, and the pressure to keep my projects moving smoothly. My chest tightened as I tried to decide which role needed me more right now.
